awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Preparing a Diverse Workforce through Interdisciplinary Astrophysics Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for renewed funding of the REU Site at Center for Interdisciplinary Exploration and Research in Astrophysics (CIERA) at Northwestern University (NU). The REU site takes advantage of CIERA's interdisciplinary nature, providing students with access to mentors across departments, and insight into the cross-departmental connections between astronomy and astrophysics and other STEM disciplines. The program will be offered annually to 8 students. The available mentors come from the departments of: Physics and Astronomy; Applied Math; Earth and Planetary Science; and Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. Available research projects cover astronomical topics and methods ranging across theory, computation, instrumentation, and experimentation. The students will have access to a wide range of cutting-edge facilities, including instrument labs and the Quest high performance computing facility at NU.

Through this exposure, the REU students will learn how astronomical studies prepare them with a wide range of skills and can lead them to diverse professional paths. NU CIERA's REU site gives students the experience of doing interdisciplinary astronomical research, exposes them to a wide array of exciting research areas in astrophysics, and builds a community among the students and NU researchers. The Site recruits a significant fraction of its participants from underrepresented groups in STEM by partnering with Chicago-area minority serving institutions. Through high-quality research experiences and profesional development activities, the NU CIERA REU Site will contribute to the development of a diverse, sophisticated, and highly competitive STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Northwestern University (NU)'s Center for Interdisciplinary Exploration and Research in Astrophysics (CIERA) continued our astrophysics REU site with this grant. CIERA is a university-level center for astrophysics which provides support for faculty, postdocs and students from across disciplines to participate in astrophysics research.

This grant was originally awarded for a 3-year term, but with cost savings during the pandemic (due to running the program remotely) and a supplement, this grant period spans from 2018 to (partially) 2022. During this grant period, we hosted 69 total REU students (supported by NSF and other funds), to pursue interdisciplinary astrophysics research for 9 weeks each summer.   Over these years, we received an average of 422 applications per year, with a maximum of 530 applications in 2019.  We received applications from students in nearly every state plus Puerto Rico and from hundreds of unique schools from across the country. These students were mentored by 24 different CIERA faculty members and co-mentored by numerous postdoctoral researchers and graduate students.  Our REUs are majoring (or majored) in a wide range of disciplines: Aerospace Engineering, Astronomy, Astrophysics, Chemistry, Computational Physics, Computer Science, Engineering Physics, English, Math, and Mathematical Sciences.  This broad range of interests reflects the interdisciplinary nature of CIERA and enriches the students' summer experience.  The summer research projects cover the breadth of research methods in astrophysics, from theory to computation and instrumentation to experimentation.

This grant provided funding for all students to attend a scientific conference to present their research.  The majority of our students accepted this offer to attend a meeting and presented research posters to their peers and professional astronomers.  Most students chose to attend and present their work at American Astronomical Society meetings.  Other students presented at the American Geophysical Union annual meeting, the Seismological Society of America meeting and the APS Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics (CUWiP).

Abstracts for most of these students' posters are available online.  Furthermore, each of our REU students created a research website, maintained by NU and CIERA, to share their research with the public (see our website URL at the end of this report).   At the end of each summer, students also shared their results with Northwestern faculty and staff, museum visitors at the Adler Planetarium in Chicago, and friends and family (on Zoom), through poster presentations. 

During this grant cycle, our REU students contributed to 18 refereed journal articles (7 as first authors) and 3 research notes (all as first authors).  Links to these papers can be found on our website, provided at the end of this report. 

We continue to make a concerted effort to maintain a diverse REU cohort: including the full duration of our REU program, 54% or our students were female, 28% were Hispanic, 12% were African American and 8% were from other minority gender or ethnic/racial groups (with some overlap between these groups).  Moreover, 74/84 (88%) of our students were either female or students from underrepresented groups in STEM.  We also strive for a diversity in student research background, home institution size and location; 45% of our REUs come from R1 universities, 26% from R2 universities, 13% from smaller regional universities, 9% from liberal arts colleges, and 6% from (2-year) community colleges.  Many of our students are first generation college-goers.  Also, approximately half of our REU cohort (each year) are from local Chicago-area schools.  Nearly all of these local students were either female or from underrepresented groups in STEM.

Of our past REU students who completed their undergraduate degree, 81% are in (or have completed) Masters or Ph.D. programs in STEM. Considering only women, the Ph.D. enrollment rate rises to 85%, and reaches 65% for students from other underrepresented groups. This Ph.D. rate for students from underrepresented groups is over nine times that of the national average of 7% in physics and astronomy (Ph.D. degree rate averaged over 2016-2020 by the American Physical Society).

In addition to the formal research experience, we focus on students' professional development and exposure to a wide range of careers.  Special effort was made to provide these REU students with research skills and the level of preparation needed to get into and thrive in graduate programs in astronomy/physics and other technical fields. In addition to a directed research project with a supportive mentor, students attended technical skills workshops (in Python coding, high performance computing, and website design), science communication workshops (including oral, written and visual presentation styles), lectures by faculty, postdocs and graduate students describing their research and career paths, grad school and career panel discussions, organized field trips, and other cohort building events.  Through both the research experience and professional development activities, our NU CIERA REU site contributes to the development of a diverse, sophisticated, and highly competitive STEM workforce.

More information can be found on our CIERA REU website: https://sites.northwestern.edu/cierareu/
